summary: Sequoia Capital's John Sutter argues that Institutional Shareholder Services, the largest of the firms offering advice to fund managers and investors about how to vote on issues at annual shareholder meetings, should not be judge and jury. He argues that ISS's influence has grown for several reasons, including the size and structure of Apple CEO Tim Cook's $99mn pay and bonuses package for 2021, and its influence was shown in the vote against the board’s pay recommendation. ISS also operates a ballot vote counting service and provides research for class action stockholder lawsuits. Companies should recruit directors willing to ignore browbeating and who structure pay packages for executives that reward them handsomely for spectacular performance, and investors and fund managers should discard their crutches and stand tall.

summary: Apple on Tuesday announced the launch of a high-end desktop computer that would leverage its successful homegrown M1 chips. The Mac Studio, starting at $1,999, is akin to a pro version of Mac Mini and connects to an external monitor. It comes as Apple looks to gain an iPhone-like market share in the desktop segment following the success of the M1 chip, the company’s first desktop processor. Apple also announced the revamped the iPhone SE, first released in 2016 and refreshed in 2020. With a starting price of $429, it is intended to lure Android users without cannibalising potential buyers of higher-margin iPhones.

summary: Apple has suspended all product sales and access to state media outlets Russia Today and Sputnik from the iPhone’s App Store outside the country. Other US brands, such as Walt Disney, Warner Bros, and Nike, have also pulled out of operations in the region. The moves underscore how western companies are shifting focus from operational concerns associated with the Ukraine invasion to questions about the reputational risks associated with business as usual. Apple has also stopped exporting products to Russia last week and followed Google Maps in disabling live traffic updates on its mapping app in Ukraine. The Federal Security Service (FSB), which oversees all imports of Russian technology, is required to notify the Russian security agency.

summary: Apple has suspended all product sales and access to state media outlets Russia Today and Sputnik from the iPhone’s App Store outside the country. Other US brands, such as Walt Disney, Warner Bros, and Nike, have also pulled out of operations in the region. The moves underscore how western companies are shifting focus from operational concerns associated with the Ukraine invasion to questions about the reputational risks associated with business as usual. Apple has also stopped exporting products to Russia last week and followed Google Maps in disabling live traffic updates on its mapping app in Ukraine. The Federal Security Service (FSB), which oversees all imports of Russian technology, is required to notify the Russian security agency.

summary: When Apple suspended sales of iPhones and other products in Russia this week, it made a subtler intervention. Google and Google also turned off traffic updates for its live mapping service in Ukraine as a precaution against the invading army using it to attack. The first external sign of the invasion came when a traffic jam caused by a military column appeared on the Ukrainian border, and was spotted on Google Maps. Maps are essential in wartime, and the visual influence of data plotted on maps was illustrated powerfully elsewhere this week with the publication of new international research into the origin of the Covid-19 outbreak in Wuhan in 2019. There is a long history of nations using maps to advance their claims to imperial possession, and Russian manipulation of maps has often involved concealment and propaganda. Enormous mapping and spatial data are now available through private providers such as Apple and Google, as well as private services such as Maxar, Capella and public databases.
